title: Ezekiel Chapter 13 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 13 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 13 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 13.

questions.question: Who did the word of the LORD come to in Ezekiel 13:1?
options: Ezekiel
Moses
David
Isaiah
questions.correctAnswer: Ezekiel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:1 states that the word of the LORD came unto Ezekiel.

questions.question: Against whom does Ezekiel prophesy in Ezekiel 13:2?
options: The prophets of Israel
The kings of Israel
The priests of Israel
The elders of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The prophets of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:2 commands to prophesy against the prophets of Israel that prophesy.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 13:3, what is the Lord's message about foolish prophets?
options: Woe unto the foolish prophets
Blessings upon the wise prophets
Peace to all prophets
Silence for the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Woe unto the foolish prophets
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:3 says, 'Woe unto the foolish prophets, that follow their own spirit, and have seen nothing!'

questions.question: In Ezekiel 13:4, the prophets of Israel are compared to what animal?
options: Foxes
Lions
Eagles
Serpents
questions.correctAnswer: Foxes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:4 states, 'O Israel, thy prophets are like the foxes in the deserts.'

questions.question: What have the prophets failed to do according to Ezekiel 13:5?
options: Go up into the gaps and make up the hedge
Build houses for the people
Gather the tribes of Israel
Offer sacrifices in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Go up into the gaps and make up the hedge
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:5 criticizes them for not going up into the gaps or making up the hedge for Israel.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 13:6 says the prophets have spoken only what the LORD sent them to say.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:6 says the prophets have spoken vanity and lying divination, claiming 'The LORD saith' though He did not send them.

questions.question: What will happen to the prophets who divine lies and see vanity according to Ezekiel 13:9?
options: They shall not be in the assembly of my people
They shall be honored
They shall receive a crown
They shall be rulers
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not be in the assembly of my people
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:9 states that such prophets shall not be in the assembly nor enter the land of Israel.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 13:10, what have the false prophets seduced the people to believe?
options: Peace
War
Famine
Darkness
questions.correctAnswer: Peace
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:10 says they have seduced the people by saying 'Peace' when there was no peace.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Ezekiel 13:11: 'Say unto them which daub it with ________ morter, that it shall fall.'
options: untempered
strong
fresh
dry
questions.correctAnswer: untempered
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:11 refers to 'untempered morter' that causes the wall to fall.

questions.question: What natural events are mentioned in Ezekiel 13:11 as causing the wall to fall?
options: Overflowing shower, great hailstones, and stormy wind
Earthquake and fire
Drought and famine
Thunder and lightning
questions.correctAnswer: Overflowing shower, great hailstones, and stormy wind
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:11 describes an overflowing shower, great hailstones, and a stormy wind that will rend the wall.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 13:16 says the prophets prophesy peace for Jerusalem, and there truly is peace.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:16 states that the prophets prophesy peace for Jerusalem, but there is no peace.

questions.question: Who are referred to as the 'daughters of thy people' in Ezekiel 13:17?
options: Women who prophesy out of their own heart
Women who are priests
Women who are queens
Women who are widows
questions.correctAnswer: Women who prophesy out of their own heart
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:17 directs Ezekiel to prophesy against the women who prophesy out of their own heart.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 13:18, what do the women sew to hunt souls?
options: Pillows to all armholes
Robes of many colors
Sashes of silk
Crowns of gold
questions.correctAnswer: Pillows to all armholes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:18 says these women sew pillows to all armholes to hunt souls.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 13:22 says the lies of the false prophets made the righteous sad.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:22 states that with lies, the prophets have made the heart of the righteous sad.

questions.question: What will God do to the lying divinations according to Ezekiel 13:23?
options: Deliver His people out of their hand
Bless their prophecies
Make them stronger
Hide them forever
questions.correctAnswer: Deliver His people out of their hand
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:23 declares God will deliver His people out of the hand of lying diviners.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 13 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 13 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting false promises from others. Based on Ezekiel 13, what biblical truth would you share about integrity and honesty?
options: False prophets who speak lies lead believers astray and bring God's judgment
It is acceptable to speak lies if it comforts others
Prophets should only speak what pleases the people
God ignores false prophesying as long as people are hopeful
questions.correctAnswer: False prophets who speak lies lead believers astray and bring God's judgment
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:6-9 warn against prophets who speak vanity and lying divinations, causing false hope. God declares His hand upon such prophets and will exclude them from His people, emphasizing honesty and integrity.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 13 teach us about perseverance through trials when facing deception within the church?
options: God will deliver His people from the hand of lying prophets and bring them back to truth
Believers should tolerate all teachings to avoid conflict
Deception is a sign that God has abandoned His people
The church must rely on human wisdom rather than God's Word
questions.correctAnswer: God will deliver His people from the hand of lying prophets and bring them back to truth
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:22-23 promises deliverance from false prophets who make the righteous sad and strengthen the wicked. This encourages believers to persevere, trusting God's restoration.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 13, what biblical principle about faith and trust in God can be taught regarding false assurances of peace?
options: Peace cannot be falsely promised; trusting God’s true word is essential
Any message of peace is from God regardless of circumstances
Peace is only found in human efforts and protections
False peace should be accepted if it encourages people
questions.correctAnswer: Peace cannot be falsely promised; trusting God’s true word is essential
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:10 and 16 criticize prophets who say 'Peace' when there is no peace, warning believers to rely on God’s true promises, not false assurances.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because others in the church mislead with empty words. Based on Ezekiel 13, what counsel about spiritual discipline and discernment would you offer?
options: Discernment is vital to avoid following those who see vanity and speak lies
All spiritual teachings should be accepted without question
Empty words are harmless if they make people feel better
Discernment is unnecessary if the speaker is popular
questions.correctAnswer: Discernment is vital to avoid following those who see vanity and speak lies
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:3-4 and 7 emphasize that some prophets follow their own spirit and see nothing true. Believers must discern truth to maintain faithfulness.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and contentment does Ezekiel 13 teach through the example of prophets who rely on their own hearts rather than God's word?
options: Humility requires submitting to God’s word rather than trusting personal visions
Contentment comes from trusting human wisdom over divine instruction
Pride is justified if one feels spiritually gifted
Self-reliance is the key to spiritual growth
questions.correctAnswer: Humility requires submitting to God’s word rather than trusting personal visions
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:2, 17-18 condemn those who prophesy out of their own hearts, highlighting the need for humility to submit to God's revelation and reject self-willed visions.

questions.question: A church leader is tempted to smooth over problems to maintain peace. According to Ezekiel 13, what biblical truth about honesty and integrity should guide their leadership?
options: Honesty is essential, even if it reveals hard truths and challenges peace
Maintaining peace justifies ignoring false teaching
Leaders should always affirm what the congregation wants to hear
Integrity means avoiding conflict at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: Honesty is essential, even if it reveals hard truths and challenges peace
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:10-15 describe false prophets who build walls with untempered mortar, symbolizing dishonesty that leads to destruction. True leadership requires honesty for lasting peace.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 13 illustrate the importance of prayer and dependence on God in spiritual leadership?
options: Leaders must rely on God’s word, not their own visions, to guide the people
Prayer is unnecessary if leaders have strong convictions
Spiritual leadership depends on personal insight and feelings
Dependence on God can be replaced with wisdom from human experience
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must rely on God’s word, not their own visions, to guide the people
questions.explanation: Verses 2-3 show that prophets who prophesy from their own hearts, rather than God’s word, are condemned. This teaches reliance on God’s guidance through prayer and Scripture.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 13, those who prophecy falsely with lying visions will be excluded from the assembly of God's people.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:9 states that God’s hand will be upon the false prophets and they will not be in the assembly of His people, nor enter the land of Israel.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 13 condemns prophets who say 'Peace' to the people when there is no peace, warning that such falsehoods will bring God’s wrath.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:10-15 clearly warn against false prophets who promise peace falsely, describing how God will break down the walls they build with untempered mortar in His fury.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 13 teaches that false prophets who build walls with untempered ________ will have their work destroyed by God’s stormy wind and hailstones.
options: mortar
stones
bricks
clay
questions.correctAnswer: mortar
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:11-14 describe how the walls built with untempered mortar by false prophets will be torn down by God’s judgment, symbolizing the collapse of false security.

questions.question: Based on Ezekiel 13, how should a Christian respond when confronted with teachings that are based on lies but promise life to the wicked?
options: Reject lies and rely on God’s truth which calls for repentance and righteousness
Accept teachings that promise life regardless of their truthfulness
Ignore false teachings to avoid conflict
Trust the majority opinion even if it contradicts Scripture
questions.correctAnswer: Reject lies and rely on God’s truth which calls for repentance and righteousness
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:19-22 condemns lying prophets who promise life to the wicked, making the righteous sad. Christians should cling to God’s truth and call for repentance.

questions.question: What practical advice about evangelism and sharing the gospel can be drawn from Ezekiel 13's warning against false prophecy?
options: Share only the true word of God, avoiding false hopes and lies
Modify the gospel message to make it more appealing
Focus on positive feelings rather than biblical truth
Avoid confronting false teaching to keep peace
questions.correctAnswer: Share only the true word of God, avoiding false hopes and lies
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13 teaches that false prophecy leads people astray and God’s judgment follows. Believers are called to share God’s true word faithfully (verses 2-3, 23).

questions.question: A parent wants to teach their children about integrity. What principle from Ezekiel 13 can help them explain the dangers of dishonesty?
options: Dishonesty leads to destruction and separation from God’s blessings
Dishonesty is acceptable if it benefits others
Small lies are harmless and do not affect faith
Integrity is only necessary in church, not daily life
questions.correctAnswer: Dishonesty leads to destruction and separation from God’s blessings
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:14-15 warns that those who daub walls with untempered mortar will be consumed, showing the destructive consequences of dishonesty.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 13 instruct believers to maintain contentment and gratitude amid false teachings and trials?
options: By trusting that God will deliver His people and uphold truth
By ignoring God's word and trusting human wisdom
By accepting all teachings to avoid distress
By withdrawing from the community to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting that God will deliver His people and uphold truth
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:23 promises God will deliver His people from false prophets, encouraging believers to be content and grateful for God’s faithfulness.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 13 teach about the work ethic of spiritual leaders and servants in the church?
options: Leaders must build on a firm foundation of God’s truth, not on vanity or lies
It is acceptable to cut corners if the outcome seems positive
Leaders should rely on their own spirit rather than God’s word
Work ethic is secondary to popularity in ministry
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must build on a firm foundation of God’s truth, not on vanity or lies
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:5 and 14 describe how false prophets fail to build a strong hedge or foundation, leading to collapse, underscoring the importance of diligent, truthful labor.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 13 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 13.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 13:3, the Lord calls certain prophets 'foolish' because they:
options: Follow their own spirit and have seen nothing
Prophesy only during times of peace
Support the king of Israel
Speak only in parables
questions.correctAnswer: Follow their own spirit and have seen nothing
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:3 states that the foolish prophets follow their own spirit and have seen nothing, which is why they are condemned.

questions.question: The metaphor of prophets being 'like the foxes in the deserts' in Ezekiel 13:4 primarily conveys what idea?
options: They are cunning but destructive
They protect the vineyards
They are faithful watchmen
They bring good news
questions.correctAnswer: They are cunning but destructive
questions.explanation: Foxes in ancient Near Eastern literature often symbolize cunning and destructive behavior; Ezekiel 13:4 uses this metaphor to portray false prophets as harmful.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 13:6, what do the false prophets claim that the LORD says?
options: Vanity and lying divination
Words of hope and peace
Judgments against the nations
Promises of restoration
questions.correctAnswer: Vanity and lying divination
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:6 explains that false prophets speak vanity and lying divination, claiming 'The LORD saith' when He has not sent them.

questions.question: Ezekiel 13:10 describes one building a wall and others daubing it with untempered morter. What does this symbolize?
options: False security based on unstable foundations
The physical rebuilding of Jerusalem's defenses
The unity of Israel's tribes
The construction of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: False security based on unstable foundations
questions.explanation: The wall with untempered morter symbolizes deceptive protection—false prophets giving a false sense of peace without true strength (Ezekiel 13:10).

questions.question: What consequence does Ezekiel 13:9 say will come upon the prophets who divine lies?
options: They shall not be in the assembly of my people
They will be exalted among the nations
They shall build a great temple
They will receive visions of peace
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not be in the assembly of my people
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:9 declares that false prophets will be excluded from the assembly, the written record of Israel, and the land itself.

questions.question: The phrase 'untempered morter' in Ezekiel 13:10-14 refers to:
options: A weak and unstable binding material
A sacred anointing oil
A type of ceremonial garment
A form of incense
questions.correctAnswer: A weak and unstable binding material
questions.explanation: Untempered morter is mortar not mixed properly, symbolizing the false prophets' faulty and unstable work in prophesying (Ezekiel 13:10-14).

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 13:16 say about the prophets who prophesy peace for Jerusalem when there is none?
options: They are condemned for false visions
They are praised for their hopefulness
They will lead the people to victory
They will be the kings of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They are condemned for false visions
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:16 condemns the prophets who falsely see and proclaim peace for Jerusalem when in fact there is no peace.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 13:18, what is the significance of the women sewing pillows to all armholes and making kerchiefs to hunt souls?
options: They symbolize deceitful practices harming God's people
They represent protective garments of the faithful
They signify mourning rituals
They are tokens of covenant loyalty
questions.correctAnswer: They symbolize deceitful practices harming God's people
questions.explanation: The imagery in Ezekiel 13:18 criticizes women who use symbolic garments to deceive and ensnare the people’s souls for personal gain.

questions.question: Ezekiel 13:20-21 describes God’s reaction to the women’s pillows and kerchiefs. What is God's declared action?
options: God will tear them from their arms and deliver the people
God will bless their craft and multiply their influence
God will ignore their actions
God will make them leaders in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: God will tear them from their arms and deliver the people
questions.explanation: Verses 20-21 state God will remove these deceptive instruments from the women and rescue His people from their influence.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 13:22, how have the false prophets affected the righteous and the wicked?
options: Made the righteous sad and strengthened the wicked
Encouraged the righteous and weakened the wicked
Brought joy to the righteous and peace to the wicked
Left both the righteous and wicked unchanged
questions.correctAnswer: Made the righteous sad and strengthened the wicked
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:22 explains that lies from false prophets caused sorrow to the righteous and emboldened the wicked to continue their ways.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 13 teaches that all visions and prophecies are from the LORD and must be accepted.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13 condemns false prophets who give vain visions and lying divinations not sent by the LORD (Ezekiel 13:6-7).

questions.question: The phrase ‘one built up a wall, and, lo, others daubed it with untempered morter’ (Ezekiel 13:10) exemplifies which literary device?
options: Parallelism
Chiasm
Typology
Foreshadowing
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The verse uses parallel structure to contrast builders and those who improperly seal the wall with untempered morter.

questions.question: How does the warning against false prophets in Ezekiel 13 relate to Jesus' teaching in Matthew 7:15 about false prophets?
options: Both warn that false prophets deceive people and bring destruction
Ezekiel encourages false prophecy; Matthew forbids it
Ezekiel focuses on priests only, Matthew on merchants
They address different nations with no overlap
questions.correctAnswer: Both warn that false prophets deceive people and bring destruction
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13 and Matthew 7:15 both warn that false prophets mislead God's people and cause harm.

questions.question: The Hebrew term translated as 'lying divination' in Ezekiel 13:6 is significant because it highlights what about the false prophets?
options: Their practice of unauthorized oracles
Their role as priests in the temple
Their possession of true revelation
Their use of incantations for healing
questions.correctAnswer: Their practice of unauthorized oracles
questions.explanation: The term emphasizes that the prophets' divinations are deceptive and not from God, showing their illegitimacy (Ezekiel 13:6).

questions.question: Ezekiel 13:14 describes God breaking down the wall to reveal its foundation. This act typologically foreshadows:
options: The ultimate judgment exposing false security
The building of the New Jerusalem
The anointing of a new king
The restoration of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: The ultimate judgment exposing false security
questions.explanation: Breaking the wall reveals the unstable foundation, symbolizing God's judgment that exposes and destroys false protection (Ezekiel 13:14).

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 13 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 13 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 13, why does God pronounce woe upon the prophets of Israel?
options: Because they prophesy out of their own hearts and see nothing
Because they refuse to speak at all
Because they preach only destruction without hope
Because they worship other gods
questions.correctAnswer: Because they prophesy out of their own hearts and see nothing
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:2-3 condemns prophets who prophesy from their own imaginations rather than God’s revelation. This is consistent with Deuteronomy 18:20-22 where false prophets are warned against, Jeremiah 23:16 which denounces prophets who speak lies, and 2 Peter 2:1 which speaks of false teachers from among the people.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 13, the prophets are compared to which animal, symbolizing their deceit and destructiveness?
options: Foxes
Wolves
Serpents
Lions
questions.correctAnswer: Foxes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:4 likens the prophets to foxes in the deserts, implying cunning and destructive behavior. This imagery aligns with Jesus’ warning about false prophets as wolves in sheep’s clothing (Matthew 7:15), and Jeremiah 5:6 which describes false prophets as foxes.

questions.question: What does God say the false prophets have failed to do for the house of Israel?
options: Build up the gaps and make the hedge to stand in the battle
Preach repentance to the people
Bring offerings to the temple
Gather the exiles from the nations
questions.correctAnswer: Build up the gaps and make the hedge to stand in the battle
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:5 criticizes prophets for neglecting to repair breaches in Israel’s spiritual defenses, symbolizing failure to protect the people from judgment. This parallels Nehemiah 4:3 regarding repairing the wall and Isaiah 58:12 about repairing breaches.

questions.question: What consequence does God declare for the prophets who divine lies and see vanity?
options: They shall not be in the assembly of His people nor enter the land of Israel
They will be rewarded with wealth and honor
They will become kings over Israel
They will receive visions from the Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not be in the assembly of His people nor enter the land of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:9 pronounces exclusion from the covenant community for false prophets, reflecting God’s holiness and judgment. This is consistent with Deuteronomy 13:5 on rejecting false prophets, and 1 Corinthians 5:11 about removing unrepentant sinners from the church.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 13, what is the metaphor used for the false prophets' deceptive promises of peace?
options: Walls daubed with untempered mortar
Gold refined in fire
A vine without fruit
A cloud without rain
questions.correctAnswer: Walls daubed with untempered mortar
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:10-14 uses the metaphor of a wall patched with untempered mortar that will collapse, illustrating the false security given by lying prophets. This imagery is echoed in Jeremiah 6:14 and 8:11 regarding deceptive peace, and Matthew 7:24-27 about building on a firm foundation.

questions.question: What does God say will happen to the wall daubed with untempered mortar?
options: It will fall in a storm with hail and flood
It will stand firm forever
It will be rebuilt stronger
It will be blessed with prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: It will fall in a storm with hail and flood
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:11-14 describes how the faulty wall will be destroyed by natural forces symbolizing divine judgment. This corresponds with the theme of God’s judgment in Psalm 18:12-15 and Isaiah 28:17 which speak of destruction for the unfaithful.

questions.question: Who are specifically condemned for prophesying peace when there is no peace?
options: The prophets of Israel concerning Jerusalem
The priests in the temple
The elders of the people
The foreign nations around Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The prophets of Israel concerning Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:16 condemns those who falsely prophesy peace about Jerusalem, reflecting God’s displeasure with false assurances. This is consistent with Jeremiah 6:14 and Ezekiel 22:28 where false prophets mislead the people with lies.

questions.question: What symbolic garments do the daughters of Israel wear when they prophesy deceitfully, according to Ezekiel 13?
options: Pillows sewn to armholes and kerchiefs on heads
Robes of fine linen and golden crowns
Sandals of iron and helmets of brass
Garments of sackcloth and ashes
questions.correctAnswer: Pillows sewn to armholes and kerchiefs on heads
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:18 describes women who prophesy falsely using symbolic pillows and kerchiefs to 'hunt souls,' indicating manipulative spiritual practices. This imagery reminds of false religious practices condemned in Revelation 2:20 and Isaiah 3:16-17.

questions.question: For what dishonest gain do these women pollute God among His people?
options: For handfuls of barley and pieces of bread
For silver and gold
For lands and houses
For political power
questions.correctAnswer: For handfuls of barley and pieces of bread
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:19 accuses these women of corrupting God’s people for small bribes, showing the sin of greed. This parallels Micah 3:11 and Amos 8:6 which condemn prophets and priests who exploit the poor for profit.

questions.question: What will God do to the pillows and kerchiefs used by these deceitful women?
options: He will tear them and deliver His people
He will sanctify them for holy use
He will hide them in secret places
He will multiply them as blessings
questions.correctAnswer: He will tear them and deliver His people
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:20-21 declares God will destroy their tools of deception and rescue His people, affirming His justice and protection. This is consistent with Isaiah 54:17 and Psalm 34:17 regarding God's deliverance of the righteous.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 13, how have these false prophets affected the hearts of the righteous and the wicked?
options: Made the righteous sad and strengthened the wicked
Encouraged both to seek repentance
Made the wicked fearful and the righteous joyful
Confused both with their messages
questions.correctAnswer: Made the righteous sad and strengthened the wicked
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:22 states lies by false prophets sadden the righteous and embolden the wicked by promising life deceitfully. This reflects Jeremiah 23:17 and Proverbs 29:12 about the harm caused by false teaching.

questions.question: What final declaration does God make about vain visions and lying divinations in Ezekiel 13?
options: They shall be seen no more because God will deliver His people
They will increase and confuse the nations
They are signs of God’s mercy
They are to be accepted if they bring peace
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be seen no more because God will deliver His people
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:23 promises an end to false visions and divinations as God rescues His people, emphasizing His sovereignty. This aligns with Isaiah 8:20 and Jeremiah 29:8-9 on rejecting false prophecy.

questions.question: What divine attribute is most clearly revealed by God's judgment on false prophets in Ezekiel 13?
options: God’s holiness and justice
God’s wrath without mercy
God’s indifference to human sin
God’s partiality towards sinners
questions.correctAnswer: God’s holiness and justice
questions.explanation: God’s condemnation of false prophecy in Ezekiel 13 reveals His holiness and commitment to justice, refusing to tolerate deceit (Ezekiel 13:8-9). This is consistent with Habakkuk 1:13, Psalm 5:4-6, and Hebrews 12:29.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 13 contribute to the biblical doctrine of salvation?
options: By showing that true salvation requires hearing God’s true word, not lies
By teaching that salvation comes through human wisdom
By emphasizing salvation by works only
By denying the need for repentance
questions.correctAnswer: By showing that true salvation requires hearing God’s true word, not lies
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13 highlights that salvation depends on receiving God’s true revelation, contrasting false prophets who mislead (Ezekiel 13:6-7). This supports John 5:24, Romans 10:17, and 2 Timothy 3:16 on the necessity of true Scripture for salvation.

questions.question: What eschatological theme is implicit in Ezekiel 13’s depiction of the day of the LORD and judgment on false prophets?
options: The coming divine judgment against sin and falsehood
The eternal reign of earthly kingdoms
The destruction of the natural world only
The salvation of all without distinction
questions.correctAnswer: The coming divine judgment against sin and falsehood
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 13:5 and following refer to the day of the LORD as a time of decisive judgment against false prophets, a key eschatological motif also found in Joel 2:31, Malachi 4:5, and 2 Thessalonians 1:6-10.
